ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Link relations [was: A media type for case files, dossiers and documents]
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I agree they are semantically equivalent.  However, the arrangement of information in an atom:link element increases the effort required to understand it.

On Tue, Nov 30, 2010 at 11:07 AM, Trygve Laugst=C3=B8l <trygvis@...> w=
rote:
> On 11/30/10 6:38 PM, Peter Williams wrote:
>>
>> 2010/11/30 Trygve =
Laugst=C5=B3l<trygvis@...>:
>>
>>> I would go for atom:link as I hope =
that everyone will converge on using
>>> atom:link [1]. The main advantage =
as I see it is that they will have
>>> less to learn and that we will will =
converge on a more stable set of
>>> relations which in turn will make it p=
ossible to create more generic
>>> code for indexing, crawling etc. Just ma=
ke sure you create and define
>>> your own rel types according to the atom =
spec [2].
>>
>> Personally i don't much like atom:link. =C2=A0It trades cla=
rity for a false
>> promise of re-use. =C2=A0The idea that a great deal of =
leverage will be
>> gained by reusing atom:link in other formats seems not =
be born out in
>> reality. =C2=A0Parsing arbitrary xml documents, looking f=
or link elements
>> and then doing things with them without understanding t=
he semantics of
>> the overall representation sounds pretty far fetched to =
me. =C2=A0(Is that
>> edit link for the requested resource, or is it for a =
different
>> resource whose information is contained in the requested one.)=

>>
>> The `<{name} href=3D""/>` pattern promotes the meaningful name of th=
e
>> item to the highest possible level. =C2=A0This increases the clarity o=
f the
>> representation. =C2=A0As a client writer i care about semantics of=
 the
>> various parts of the representations far more than i care about the=
ir
>> types. =C2=A0I can guess with little effort that an element named 'ed=
it'
>> will contain a link. =C2=A0With a link element i must scan to the ri=
ght
>> until i find the @rel in order to understand the purpose of the
>> e=
lement. =C2=A0I'll take clarity over vague, unrealistic, promises of
>> re-=
use any day.
>
> To me <atom:link rel=3D"{name}" href=3D""/> is equal to <{=
name} href=3D""/>.

I agree they are semantically equivalent.  However, the=
 arrangement of
information in an atom:link element increases the effort re=
quired to
understand it.  Not much of course, but a little.  I prefer not t=
o
intentionally increase the complexity of my representations unless it
pro=
vide a very real benefit.

>> Besides, we have the link header[1] which is =
better, in every
>> imaginable way, than atom:link for expressing common re=
lations. =C2=A0It
>> does not require the client be able to parse a particu=
lar format and
>> it unambiguously relates the link to the requested resour=
ce as a
>> whole.
>
>>
>>
>> [1]:<http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988>
>
> L=
ink headers is mostly useful for linking *entire resources* to other
> *res=
ources* while atom:link gives you a more fine grained linking mechanism.
> =
I'm not against link headers in anyway, just saying it's a slightly
> diffe=
rent thing.

Exactly.  The ambiguity of link elements (due to their fine
gr=
ainedness) works against any real world re-use of them.  Clien have
to unde=
rstand the whole representation that contains link elements in
order to use=
 those links.  Therefore, there is little, or no,
practical benefit to usin=
g atom:link elements but there is some cost.

Peter
barelyenough.org
